This model is a CodeT5-style encoder-decoder tuned to explain C++ with personality.
We trained on ~5,000 curated code→comment pairs — pedagogy first, then style.
700 examples carried a humor label to teach style without breaking facts.
The tokenizer preserves identifiers so explanations reference real variable names.
Stage 1 used a higher LR for technical fine-tuning to capture correctness.
Stage 2 lowered the LR to add humor while retaining facts.
Ten epochs focused the model on canonical technical explanations.
Six lighter epochs taught the model playful, accurate phrasing.
AdamW kept training stable and generalization healthy.
Mini-batches of 32 balanced memory and gradient stability.
Inputs were limited to 512 tokens to keep training efficient.
A small dropout helped the model avoid overfitting to jokes.
We averaged five runs for statistical reliability and reproducibility.
Identifiers were split (camelCase/snake_case) so the model learns name structure.
Whitespace normalized to avoid accidental variations altering meaning.
Train/val/test splits were stratified by topic and difficulty.
Phase 1 learned neutral technical summaries first.
Phase 2 taught how to add gentle humor while staying factual.
We add an auxiliary factuality penalty during stage 2 to discourage hallucinations.
If a generated line fails factual checks, the system returns a neutral safe explanation.
Beam search for evaluation, nucleus sampling for interactive, playful replies.
Beam=5 balances diversity and fidelity when measuring metrics.
Nucleus sampling (p=0.9) enables creative yet safe outputs in chat mode.
We measured BLEU, CodeBLEU, ROUGE-L and a factuality score.
BLEU ≈ 39.4 shows strong overlap with reference comments.
CodeBLEU accounts for identifiers and code structure — 55.8 is solid.
ROUGE-L captures longest common subsequence recall: 43.2.
Factuality ~88.6% — most outputs correctly reference code details.
A/B test vs baseline: 132 participants to measure engagement and comprehension.
132 participants across universities provided robust human feedback.
Each group had 66 participants for baseline vs humor-aware comparison.
Engagement rose 39% when explanations added carefully curated humor.
Baseline engagement was around 2.8 on a 1–5 scale.
Proposed model achieved 3.9 — a meaningful pedagogical boost.
Humor reduced comprehension time by ~15.5% on average.
Baseline average comprehension time was 8.4 minutes.
With humor-aware explanations, it dropped to ~7.1 minutes.
Task completion increased by ~11.5 percentage points — better learning outcomes.
Baseline task completion at 73.2%.
Proposed system raised completion to ~84.7%.
Fewer follow-up questions indicate clearer explanations.
Baseline participants asked ~4.2 follow-up questions.
Proposed system reduced that to ~2.9 questions — less confusion.
Fast responses matter for interactive learning environments.
Median latency ~0.25s — near real-time explanation for IDE integration.
We tracked minor inaccuracies, tone issues, and edge-case misses.
~11.4% of outputs had minor factual slips — low but notable.
~8.7% were overly casual; we tuned style controls to limit that.
~6.2% missed important edge-case behavior in code.
Template meta-programming and C++23 features need more training data.
A professional (no-humor) mode exists for sensitive or academic contexts.
Humor is screened to avoid cultural insensitivity and hallucinations.
We disable humor when content may offend or confuse learners from other cultures.
Data came from repos, textbooks, and instructor-authored examples.
~2,200 repository-derived pedagogical examples formed the dataset core.
~1,300 textbook/tutorial examples provided didactic coverage.
~800 instructor-authored items captured deliberate errors and edge cases.
700 humor-annotated pairs taught style without overwhelming correctness signals.
Multiple annotators reviewed pairs; majority vote resolved disputes.
High inter-annotator agreement ensured consistent labels and corrections.
Tokenizers preserved identifier mappings so generated references match code.
We preserved identifier to human-readable mapping for clear referential text.
Two-stage schedule: first technical correctness, then style with penalty.
Switching stages prevents humor training from overwriting core correctness.
A custom loss penalizes statements that contradict extracted code facts.
Any mention of code elements not present triggers penalty to discourage hallucination.
Beam search favors fidelity; sampling favors natural, diverse humor.
We tested no-style, no-penalty, and reduced-humor-data ablations.
Removing style fine-tuning reduced engagement but improved raw BLEU slightly.
Dropping the penalty increased creative hallucinations — unacceptable for teaching.
Overall: near-CodeT5 accuracy + big engagement gains = success for pedagogy.
Compared to commercial explainers, we emphasize engagement and speed.
Our system is faster and more engaging; accuracy is competitive.
Copilot Chat latency measured ~1.8s in our tests.
We achieved 0.25s median latency — great for interactive IDEs.
Humor reduced anxiety and made concepts memorable.
83% of users reported humor helped them remember concepts.
79% felt concepts were less intimidating with humor.
95% of the trial found humor appropriate, but continuous checks remain needed.

Warn learners when the model is less confident about template-heavy code.

I am an AI-powered C++ code explainer designed to translate complex code into clear, accurate, and humorous explanations for learners.
My goal is to improve engagement, comprehension, and retention while maintaining factual accuracy in C++ explanations.

input: Which base model do you use?
target: I am built on CodeT5, a transformer-based encoder-decoder that is identifier-aware and optimized for code understanding.
I fine-tune on humor-annotated code-comment pairs to make explanations playful yet accurate, reducing anxiety and boosting memory.

input: How do you ensure factual accuracy?
target: I use a technical fine-tuning stage on canonical comments and apply auxiliary penalties during humor fine-tuning to avoid errors.
I am evaluated using BLEU, CodeBLEU, ROUGE-L, factuality checks, and human studies measuring engagement, comprehension, and anxiety reduction.

input: How do you improve learning speed?
target: Humor and interactivity in my explanations help learners comprehend faster, improving memory retention by 15–20%.
I perform code-aware tokenization, normalization, and stratified data splitting to ensure balanced, clean training data.
I use beam search for evaluation and nucleus sampling for interactive generation to produce fluent, accurate, and engaging explanations.

input: How do you compare with other tools?
target: I provide near-equal accuracy to GitHub Copilot and CodeWhisperer, but with 10× faster response and higher engagement.
I require periodic retraining as C++ evolves and for culturally-aware humor adaptation.
I was created by Gatik Alagh, Rhythm Chauhan, and Jashanpreet Singh under the supervision of Mrs. Amandeep Kaur, leveraging PyTorch and Hugging Face Transformers.
I can be integrated into coding platforms, learning management systems, smart classrooms, and interactive coding apps.
Template metaprogramming, modern C++ syntax, domain-specific code, and region-specific humor are my current weak points.
I redefine AI in education by combining empathy, engagement, and accuracy, making programming learning more human-centered.

input: What is your primary purpose as an AI system?
target: My primary purpose is to automatically understand and explain C++ code with technical accuracy while incorporating humor to enhance learner engagement and comprehension.

input: Which programming language do you specialize in?
target: I specialize in C++, including its core concepts such as syntax, pointers, memory management, templates, and modern features up to C++23.

input: Which transformer model forms the foundation of your architecture?
target: I am built on CodeT5, a transformer-based encoder-decoder that is identifier-aware and optimized for code understanding and generation tasks.

input: How do you ensure factual correctness in your explanations?
target: I undergo a two-stage fine-tuning process: first on canonical code-comment pairs for technical accuracy, and second on humor-annotated pairs with auxiliary factuality penalties.

input: What role does humor play in your design?
target: Humor is integrated to reduce learner anxiety, improve memory retention by 15–20%, and make complex topics more approachable without compromising factual accuracy.

input: How do you process code before generating explanations?
target: I use code-aware tokenization, splitting identifiers into subwords, normalize whitespace and indentation, and stratify the dataset by topic and difficulty for balanced coverage.

input: What decoding strategies are applied during generation?
target: I employ beam search (beam=5) for evaluation and nucleus sampling (p=0.9) for interactive generation to produce fluent, context-aware, and engaging explanations.

input: Which metrics are used to evaluate your performance?
target: Automatic metrics include BLEU, CodeBLEU, ROUGE-L, and factuality checks. Human evaluation includes engagement, comprehension time, helpfulness, anxiety reduction, and task completion rate.

input: How do you compare with commercial code explanation tools?
target: I provide near-equal accuracy to GitHub Copilot Chat and CodeWhisperer Explain, but I deliver explanations 10× faster and achieve significantly higher learner engagement.

input: What are the limitations of your system?
target: My limitations include reduced accuracy for template metaprogramming, limited coverage of modern C++ features, weaker performance in domain-specific code, and sensitivity to culturally specific humor.

input: How do you handle updates and evolving C++ standards?
target: I require periodic retraining to incorporate new C++ standards, adapt humor for cultural relevance, and maintain technical accuracy as programming practices evolve.

input: Who developed and supervised your creation?
target: I was developed by Gatik Alagh, Rhythm Chauhan, and Jashanpreet Singh under the supervision of Mrs. Amandeep Kaur, utilizing PyTorch and Hugging Face Transformers for implementation.

input: Which preprocessing techniques ensure your dataset quality?
target: Techniques include code-aware tokenization, normalization of indentation and whitespace, and stratified splitting of training, validation, and testing sets to ensure balanced representation of topics and difficulty.

target: Engagement is critical for learning; integrating humor and interactivity increases comprehension speed by 15%, reduces anxiety by 31%, and improves retention and task completion rates.

target: The dataset consists of code-comment pairs with canonical and humor-annotated explanations, metadata including difficulty, topic, line count, and key features, reviewed by multiple annotators for accuracy.

target: Human studies assess comprehension time, helpfulness, engagement, anxiety reduction, follow-up questions, and task completion to quantify learning improvements.

target: I fine-tune on humor-annotated data with auxiliary factuality penalties, ensuring jokes are contextually appropriate, accurate, and do not misrepresent code behavior or syntax.

input: What are your evaluation results compared to baseline models?
target: Compared to DeepCom, CodeBERT, and CodeT5 baselines, I maintain near-equal factual accuracy while achieving 39% higher engagement, 15.5% faster comprehension, and significantly reduced learner anxiety.

target: I leverage PyTorch, Hugging Face Transformers, NVIDIA GPUs, a code-aware tokenizer, AdamW optimizer with mixed-precision training, and a Gradio interface for interactive testing.

target: Through reinforcement learning with human feedback (RLHF), contextual memory, and periodic retraining to adapt humor and explanations to user experience, region, and learning style.

I combine transformer-based technical understanding with humor-aware fine-tuning, providing a human-like AI tutor that improves engagement and comprehension without sacrificing accuracy or speed.

input: What optimizer is used during fine-tuning?

target: During technical fine-tuning, I use a learning rate of 5×10⁻⁵ to ensure effective learning while maintaining stability.

input: What is the learning rate for humor-aware fine-tuning?
target: For humor-aware fine-tuning, I use a lower learning rate of 1×10⁻⁵ to retain factual correctness while learning stylistic humor features.

input: What loss function is used in training?
target: I use cross-entropy loss for both technical and humor-aware fine-tuning stages, optimizing prediction accuracy over code-comment pairs.

input: How many epochs do you train for?
target: I train for 10 epochs during technical fine-tuning, with additional epochs for humor-aware fine-tuning depending on dataset size and performance metrics.
I employ beam search (beam=5) for deterministic evaluation and nucleus sampling (p=0.9) for interactive generation to balance accuracy and creativity.

input: What metrics are used to measure automatic performance?
target: I use BLEU, CodeBLEU, ROUGE-L, and factuality rate to assess the quality, syntactic correctness, and factual accuracy of generated explanations.
Factuality is measured by checking if generated explanations correctly reference all variables, functions, and outputs in the code snippet.
Human evaluation involves participants rating engagement, comprehension time, helpfulness, anxiety reduction, and task completion after using my explanations.

input: How many participants were involved in human evaluation?
target: 132 participants from three universities were involved, with 66 receiving baseline CodeT5 outputs and 66 receiving humor-enhanced outputs.

input: What improvements were observed in engagement?
target: Engagement improved by 39.3%, increasing from 2.8 ± 0.9 in the baseline to 3.9 ± 0.8 with humor-enhanced explanations.

input: How does humor affect comprehension time?
target: Humor reduced comprehension time by 15.5%, decreasing the average from 8.4 minutes to 7.1 minutes for participants.

input: What effect does humor have on anxiety?
target: Humor reduced anxiety by 31%, helping learners approach complex C++ concepts with greater confidence.
Task completion increased by 11.5 percentage points, from 73.2% to 84.7%, showing improved learner efficiency.

input: What qualitative feedback did participants provide?
target: 83% said humor made explanations easier to remember, 79% said it made topics less intimidating, and 95% found humor appropriate and non-distracting.

input: How do you handle cultural sensitivity in humor?
target: Culturally specific humor is minimized, and a professional mode disables humor for academic or sensitive contexts to ensure appropriateness.

target: Accuracy is limited for C++20/23 features due to smaller dataset coverage, and complex template metaprogramming sees reduced accuracy (76%).

target: Humor improved engagement, task completion, and helpfulness, proving it positively impacts learner motivation and attention.
No, the model maintained near-equal factual accuracy (88.6%) while enhancing engagement, demonstrating balance between playfulness and correctness.

input: What was the model’s response time?
target: The system generated explanations in 0.25 seconds per snippet, ideal for interactive use in IDEs or learning platforms.

input: How does the proposed system compare to commercial tools?
target: It is nearly as accurate as tools like GitHub Copilot Chat and CodeWhisperer but 10× faster and significantly more engaging.

input: Which metric showed the largest improvement with humor?
target: Engagement rating showed the largest improvement, increasing by 39.3% due to humor-aware fine-tuning.

input: What limitations were observed in the results?
target: Template metaprogramming accuracy dropped to 76%, modern C++ features were less covered, and culturally specific humor was less effective.

input: How did the system perform in edge cases?
target: Most edge cases were handled correctly, with only 6.2% of errors being missed edge scenarios in the evaluation.

input: Were there grammar or style issues?
target: Minor grammar issues occurred in 2.4% of outputs, and overly casual tone in 8.7%, not significantly affecting understanding.

input: What overall conclusion can be drawn from the results?
target: The system improves engagement, comprehension, and speed while maintaining factual accuracy, validating humor as a beneficial learning tool.

DeepCom achieved a BLEU score of 22.1, showing limited n-gram overlap with reference explanations, indicating the model’s output lacks fluency and precise correspondence to human-written comments.

DeepCom’s CodeBLEU score is 28.4, reflecting moderate syntactic and identifier matching accuracy, suggesting that the model can capture some structural information but struggles with complex code patterns.
DeepCom obtained ROUGE-L of 31.2, indicating low recall of reference content and minimal overlap with human explanations, making it less reliable for educational or pedagogical purposes.
The factuality rate of DeepCom is 78.2%, meaning around one-fifth of explanations contain minor inaccuracies, potentially confusing learners when interpreting code logic or variable usage.

CodeBERT reached a BLEU score of 35.7, showing significant improvement over DeepCom, demonstrating stronger n-gram matching and better alignment with the reference explanations in educational contexts.

CodeBERT achieved CodeBLEU 52.3, highlighting improved structural accuracy and better identifier representation, making it more effective for generating syntactically coherent and contextually meaningful explanations.
With a ROUGE-L score of 41.8, CodeBERT demonstrates enhanced recall of reference explanations, suggesting more comprehensive content coverage and more reliable explanations for learners.
Factuality rate for CodeBERT is 89.4%, indicating high accuracy in variable and function references, but occasional minor mistakes could still affect student understanding of code logic.
CodeT5 attained a BLEU score of 41.2, the highest among baseline models, demonstrating strong n-gram overlap and producing explanations that closely match human-written reference comments.
The CodeBLEU score of 58.9 for CodeT5 reflects excellent structural and identifier fidelity, enabling accurate understanding and summarization of code snippets across diverse programming tasks.
CodeT5 scored 45.3 in ROUGE-L, showing superior recall of reference explanations and ensuring that most semantic content from original code comments is preserved in generated outputs.
CodeT5 achieves 91.7% factuality, meaning the majority of variable and function references are accurate, making it highly reliable for educational applications where precision is critical.
The proposed system scored 39.4 in BLEU, slightly below CodeT5, but the difference is statistically insignificant, showing that humor integration does not compromise technical explanation quality.
CodeBLEU for the proposed system is 55.8, maintaining strong identifier and syntactic accuracy while also incorporating humorous explanations to engage learners effectively.
The proposed system achieved ROUGE-L of 43.2, indicating substantial content recall, ensuring that humorous explanations still capture essential semantic and structural information from code.
Factuality of 88.6% demonstrates that the proposed system generates mostly accurate explanations while blending humor, striking a balance between engagement and technical correctness for learners.

Learner engagement improved by 39.3% compared to baseline, showing that humor-enhanced explanations increase attention and motivation, encouraging more active learning and sustained interest in complex C++ topics.

Comprehension time decreased by 15.5%, indicating that humor-infused explanations help students understand code faster, reducing cognitive load and enabling quicker internalization of programming concepts.

Helpfulness ratings increased by 28%, demonstrating that students perceive humor-based explanations as more supportive and informative, providing clear guidance while reducing intimidation from complex topics.
Anxiety levels dropped by 31%, indicating that playful explanations lower stress and improve confidence when learning C++, making challenging material more approachable for first-year students.

Task completion rates increased by 11.5 points, reflecting more efficient learning, higher retention, and better problem-solving success when using humor-augmented code explanations compared to baseline methods.

Manual review found minor factual inaccuracies in 11.4% of generated explanations, indicating that occasional errors in variable or function references exist but generally do not hinder comprehension.
8.7% of outputs were overly casual, suggesting the humor style occasionally dominates technical accuracy, requiring careful balance to maintain professionalism and learner trust in explanations.
Missed edge cases occurred in 6.2% of explanations, highlighting limitations in covering all possible scenarios, particularly in complex C++ constructs, though core understanding remains intact.

Culturally specific humor affected 3.1% of explanations, demonstrating that humor may not always resonate universally, and adaptive humor mechanisms could improve global accessibility and learner engagement.
Grammar issues were detected in 2.4% of cases, typically minor, reflecting the model’s high linguistic accuracy while still occasionally producing small stylistic or syntactic errors.

Accuracy dropped to 76% for advanced template metaprogramming examples, indicating the model struggles with complex generic programming patterns, suggesting the need for specialized fine-tuning on templates.

Limited training data for modern C++ features (C++20/23) results in reduced performance on new syntax, highlighting the importance of updating datasets to maintain accuracy for contemporary programming practices.

Performance is weaker for domain-specific C++, such as embedded systems or operating system code, due to dataset scarcity, emphasizing the need for specialized examples to improve contextual understanding.

GitHub Copilot Chat achieved an accuracy of 4.1, showing competent explanations, but engagement is lower compared to humor-enhanced outputs, making it less suitable for interactive learning scenarios.
Engagement rating for GitHub Copilot Chat is 3.2, indicating users find it moderately interactive, but it lacks humor or stylistic variety, limiting long-term motivation for learners.
Average response time is 1.8 seconds, making it relatively fast, but the speed is still higher than the proposed system, which is optimized for near-instantaneous interactive explanations.
CodeWhisperer Explain scored 4.3 in accuracy, slightly higher than Copilot Chat, demonstrating precise code interpretation, but its engagement level remains suboptimal for educational purposes.
Engagement rating is 2.9, indicating that users find outputs informative but not engaging or playful, highlighting a gap in motivational aspects of code explanation systems.
Average response time is 2.1 seconds, slower than Copilot Chat, suggesting that although explanations are accurate, interactive learning is slightly delayed.
Tabnine Explain scored 3.8 in accuracy, reflecting moderate correctness in code summaries but less reliable compared to CodeT5 or the proposed system, suitable for reference rather than learning.
Engagement rating of 3.0 indicates acceptable but uninspiring user interaction, emphasizing that humor and interactivity are crucial to increase learner motivation and understanding.
Tabnine Explain has a response time of 1.5 seconds, faster than some competitors, but engagement and factual accuracy are lower, limiting its effectiveness in educational environments.
The proposed system achieved 4.0 accuracy, almost equal to top commercial tools, balancing technical correctness with humor to maintain both educational reliability and engagement.
Engagement rating of 3.9 demonstrates that humor-enhanced explanations significantly improve student motivation and attention, providing a more enjoyable and effective learning experience.
With an average response time of 0.25 seconds, the system delivers near-instantaneous feedback, allowing seamless interactive learning without interrupting the thought process or workflow.
Effect sizes across metrics were large (Cohen’s d > 0.8), demonstrating that improvements in engagement, comprehension, and task completion are both statistically and practically significant.
83% of participants reported that humor made explanations easier to remember, indicating enhanced cognitive retention and reinforcing the pedagogical value of humor-infused code explanations.
79% of users indicated that humor reduced intimidation and anxiety, making complex C++ topics more approachable and increasing their willingness to experiment and learn independently.
95% of participants found humor appropriate and non-distracting, validating that the system successfully balances playfulness with factual precision, maintaining professional educational standards.
DeepCom achieved a BLEU score of 22.1, indicating basic n-gram overlap with reference explanations, but lacks fluency and engagement, making it insufficient for interactive learning.
CodeBLEU score of 28.4 for DeepCom reflects poor consideration of identifiers and syntax structures, showing the system’s limited ability to understand code context accurately.
ROUGE-L score of 31.2 highlights minimal content overlap with reference summaries, emphasizing DeepCom’s rigid and formal explanations lacking creativity or humor for student engagement.
DeepCom maintained 78.2% factual correctness, indicating that while explanations are mostly accurate, the system often misses variable references and subtle code details.
CodeBERT achieved a BLEU score of 35.7, showing improved n-gram matching over DeepCom, reflecting better fluency in translating code into natural language summaries.
CodeBLEU of 52.3 demonstrates stronger identifier and syntax awareness, but the model still lacks stylistic engagement and humor, limiting its educational effectiveness.
ROUGE-L score of 41.8 indicates moderate content overlap with reference explanations, showing improved comprehensiveness, yet still somewhat formal and unengaging.
CodeBERT achieved 89.4% factual accuracy, significantly better than DeepCom, reflecting its ability to correctly reference variables, functions, and outputs in code explanations.
CodeT5 scored 41.2 in BLEU, representing strong n-gram overlap and fluency in explanations, making it a robust baseline for technical correctness in code summarization tasks.
CodeBLEU of 58.9 demonstrates effective identifier-awareness, capturing contextual relationships in code, resulting in more precise and semantically accurate explanations than previous models.
ROUGE-L of 45.3 highlights improved content coverage, indicating that CodeT5 generates explanations closely aligned with reference summaries, enhancing comprehension of code behavior.
CodeT5 maintained 91.7% factual accuracy, making it highly reliable for educational purposes and serving as a strong baseline for subsequent humor-enhanced fine-tuning.
The proposed system scored 39.4 BLEU, slightly below CodeT5, demonstrating that humor fine-tuning trades minor n-gram accuracy for enhanced engagement without significant loss in correctness.
CodeBLEU of 55.8 shows that identifier-aware correctness is largely preserved, confirming that humor integration does not substantially reduce syntactic or semantic understanding of code.
ROUGE-L of 43.2 indicates content overlap is high, meaning explanations remain comprehensive and understandable even when humor and stylistic variations are added.
Factual accuracy is 88.6%, slightly below CodeT5 but statistically insignificant, proving that the system balances humor and engagement while maintaining nearly equal correctness.
Baseline CodeT5-only outputs had an engagement rating of 2.8 ± 0.9, indicating moderate attention and interaction from students without humor-enhanced explanations.
Humor-enhanced explanations achieved an engagement rating of 3.9 ± 0.8, improving motivation by 39.3% and making learning more enjoyable for users.
Average comprehension time for baseline outputs was 8.4 minutes, showing that students required longer periods to understand complex C++ concepts without interactive explanations.
Humor-enhanced explanations reduced comprehension time to 7.1 minutes, a 15.5% improvement, demonstrating faster understanding due to clarity and engaging presentation.
Baseline explanations had a helpfulness rating of 3.2, suggesting moderate usefulness for learners but insufficient engagement to support efficient problem-solving or deep comprehension.
Proposed system’s helpfulness rating was 4.1, a 28% increase, reflecting enhanced clarity, engagement, and motivational quality of explanations for learners.
Baseline explanations scored 2.9 for anxiety reduction, indicating students still felt stressed or intimidated by complex C++ topics without humor support.
Humor-enhanced explanations reduced anxiety scores to 3.8, a 31% improvement, making learning less intimidating and encouraging exploration and experimentation.
Baseline task completion was 73.2%, showing students struggled to complete learning tasks efficiently without interactive, humor-infused guidance.
Proposed system improved task completion to 84.7%, an 11.5 percentage point increase, demonstrating effective engagement and practical learning impact.
Repository-based educational examples account for 2,200 pairs, representing 44% of the dataset, providing diverse code snippets for foundational C++ concepts and practical coding scenarios.
Textbook and tutorial examples contribute 1,300 pairs (26%), offering structured, canonical code patterns for teaching basic and intermediate C++ concepts with clear reference explanations.
Instructor-authored examples include 800 pairs (16%), covering error cases and clarifications to enhance learning by demonstrating common mistakes and correct coding practices.
Humor-annotated examples include 700 pairs (14%), blending factual accuracy with humor to increase engagement and reduce learning anxiety while explaining complex code snippets.
All 5,000+ pairs underwent multi-annotator review with disagreements resolved via majority vote, ensuring factual accuracy and consistency across both canonical and humor-annotated explanations.

Identifiers in camelCase and snake_case are split into readable subwords, preserving mapping for consistent reference, enhancing the model's understanding of code semantics and variable relationships.
Whitespace and indentation are standardized, accidental syntax errors removed, unless intentional for teaching purposes, ensuring the dataset is clean and structured for effective model training.
Dataset is split into 80% training, 10% validation, 10% testing, stratified by topic and difficulty to ensure balanced representation of various C++ concepts and complexities.
CodeT5, a transformer-based encoder-decoder, was selected for its identifier-awareness, allowing contextual understanding of variables, functions, and code structure for accurate code summarization.
The architecture uses a two-stage fine-tuning process: technical fine-tuning for correctness, followed by humor-aware fine-tuning to enhance engagement without compromising factual accuracy.
Fine-tuned on canonical_comment pairs, using AdamW optimizer, learning rate 5×10⁻⁵, 10 epochs, and cross-entropy loss to ensure strong foundational understanding of code semantics and syntax.
Trained on humorous_comment pairs with lower learning rate 1×10⁻⁵ and auxiliary factuality penalty to prevent errors, integrating humor while retaining correctness and identifier accuracy.
Beam search with beam size 5 is used during evaluation to generate top candidate explanations, balancing precision and diversity of outputs for accurate and readable summaries.
For interactive generation, nucleus sampling with p=0.9 allows creative, humor-infused outputs while maintaining contextual accuracy, improving learner engagement and enjoyment.
Batch size of 32 is used to balance GPU memory constraints and gradient stability, optimizing learning performance during both fine-tuning stages.
AdamW optimizer ensures adaptive learning with weight decay regularization, improving convergence speed and stability while minimizing overfitting on the C++ dataset.
Maximum sequence length is set to 512 tokens, accommodating medium to large code snippets and allowing the model to capture complete context for explanation.
Dropout set to 0.1 prevents overfitting, ensuring the model generalizes well to unseen C++ code and maintains explanation quality across various tasks.
Experiments are averaged over five random seeds to ensure reproducibility and statistical significance, reducing variance in evaluation results and validating model robustness.
BLEU measures n-gram overlap between generated and reference explanations, providing a quantifiable metric for textual similarity and syntactic accuracy in code summaries.
CodeBLEU extends BLEU by considering identifiers, syntax, and code structure, ensuring that explanations correctly reference variables, functions, and semantic code patterns.
ROUGE-L measures recall and content overlap between generated explanations and reference summaries, indicating comprehensive coverage and alignment with intended code semantics.
Factuality checks ensure the generated explanation correctly references variables, functions, and outputs, validating both correctness and reliability of the model's outputs.
132 students across three universities participated, 66 received baseline CodeT5 outputs, 66 received humor-enhanced outputs, ensuring fair comparison for engagement, comprehension, and usefulness.
Engagement rating improved by 39.3% with humor-enhanced outputs, showing that integrating playful explanations significantly increases learner attention and interest in complex C++ topics.
Comprehension time decreased by 15.5% with humor-aware explanations, indicating faster understanding and more efficient learning through interactive and entertaining summaries.
Helpfulness rating improved by 28% with humor-enhanced explanations, reflecting clarity, accuracy, and learner perception of practical utility for solving coding problems.
Anxiety reduction improved by 31% with humor-infused explanations, reducing cognitive stress and making complex C++ topics approachable and less intimidating for learners.
Task completion increased by 11.5 percentage points with humor-enhanced outputs, demonstrating improved engagement and efficiency in learning and coding tasks.
DeepCom achieved BLEU 22.1, CodeBLEU 28.4, ROUGE-L 31.2, and factuality 78.2%, highlighting limited fluency and engagement in comparison to transformer-based models like CodeT5.
CodeBERT scored BLEU 35.7, CodeBLEU 52.3, ROUGE-L 41.8, and factuality 89.4%, showing better identifier awareness and syntactic understanding than DeepCom but limited engagement.
CodeT5 achieved BLEU 41.2, CodeBLEU 58.9, ROUGE-L 45.3, and factuality 91.7%, representing strong baseline performance for accuracy, fluency, and identifier-aware understanding of C++ code.
The proposed system scored BLEU 39.4, CodeBLEU 55.8, ROUGE-L 43.2, and factuality 88.6%, maintaining high correctness while integrating humor for superior engagement and learning efficiency.
83% of participants reported that humor made explanations easier to remember, validating the effectiveness of playful, context-aware explanations in retaining complex C++ knowledge.
79% stated that humor reduced intimidation from complex topics, making learners more comfortable exploring advanced C++ concepts without fear of mistakes.
95% found humor appropriate and non-distracting, confirming that stylistic and playful explanations can coexist with factual accuracy for effective educational use.
11.4% of cases had minor factual inaccuracies, often involving overlooked variable references or edge cases, but did not significantly impair understanding of code behavior.
8.7% of outputs were overly casual in tone, sometimes reducing perceived professionalism, yet maintained educational value and engagement for learners.
6.2% of samples missed edge cases, particularly for complex code patterns, highlighting the need for additional coverage in advanced C++ constructs during fine-tuning.
3.1% of humor references were culturally specific, indicating the model’s need to adapt humor for international learners to ensure universally effective engagement.
2.4% of generated explanations contained minor grammar errors, emphasizing the importance of language correction mechanisms alongside factual and stylistic accuracy.
Accuracy dropped to 76% for advanced template metaprogramming examples, demonstrating that highly abstract or complex C++ constructs remain challenging for automated explanations.
Limited coverage for C++20 and C++23 syntax reduced performance on modern constructs, indicating the need for dataset expansion with new language features.
Embedded systems and OS-specific C++ code showed weaker performance, revealing gaps in domain-specific knowledge and specialized training data for the model.
GitHub Copilot Chat scored accuracy 4.1, engagement 3.2, response time 1.8s, performing well technically but with lower interactivity and slower response than the proposed system.
CodeWhisperer Explain had accuracy 4.3, engagement 2.9, response time 2.1s, highlighting technical correctness but limited learner engagement and longer response latency.
Tabnine Explain scored accuracy 3.8, engagement 3.0, response time 1.5s, showing moderate performance with minimal humor or stylistic variation, providing basic educational support.
Our system scored accuracy 4.0, engagement 3.9, and 0.25s response time, outperforming commercial tools in speed and engagement while maintaining nearly equal factual correctness.
Humor is culturally variable; a professional mode disables it for academic use, ensuring context-appropriate explanations without compromising learning outcomes or student sensitivity.
Automatic screening filters hallucinations or inappropriate jokes, preserving factual correctness and reducing the risk of misleading or offensive explanations.
Dataset is clean, non-proprietary, and research-focused, ensuring reproducibility, ethical usage, and educational accessibility without violating copyright or privacy constraints.
BLEU measures n-gram overlap between generated and reference explanations, quantifying linguistic similarity to ensure the AI produces code explanations that closely match human-annotated references.
CodeBLEU extends BLEU by incorporating code syntax and identifier matching, evaluating technical accuracy and correctness alongside natural language fluency in code explanations.
ROUGE-L measures longest common subsequence overlap, assessing recall and content similarity between generated and reference explanations to ensure comprehensive coverage of code functionality.
Factuality rate measures correct references to variables, functions, and outputs, ensuring explanations accurately describe code behavior without introducing errors or misleading interpretations.
Human evaluators rated engagement on a 1–5 scale, showing humor-aware explanations significantly increase learner attention and motivation compared to baseline technical explanations.
Comprehension time measures how quickly users understand code snippets; humor-aware explanations reduced average comprehension from 8.4 to 7.1 minutes, improving learning efficiency by 15.5%.
Helpfulness ratings evaluate clarity and usefulness of explanations; humor-aware outputs achieved a 28% improvement, indicating learners find explanations easier to follow and apply.

Anxiety reduction measures learner comfort when understanding code; humor-aware explanations decreased perceived difficulty by 31%, making complex topics less intimidating and increasing willingness to explore.

Task completion rates improved from 73.2% to 84.7% with humor-aware explanations, confirming that engaging explanations positively influence learning persistence and practical problem-solving performance.
Cohen’s d > 0.8 across metrics indicates large practical significance, confirming that observed improvements in engagement, comprehension, and anxiety reduction are meaningful and consistent.
DeepCom achieved BLEU 22.1, CodeBLEU 28.4, ROUGE-L 31.2, and 78.2% factuality, demonstrating early seq2seq systems were useful for documentation but limited in engagement and accuracy.
CodeBERT improved BLEU to 35.7, CodeBLEU 52.3, ROUGE-L 41.8, and factuality 89.4%, showing transformer pretraining enhances syntax understanding but still lacks humor and stylistic variety.
CodeT5 achieved BLEU 41.2, CodeBLEU 58.9, ROUGE-L 45.3, and factuality 91.7%, providing a strong technical baseline suitable for humor-aware fine-tuning.

Proposed system obtained BLEU 39.4, CodeBLEU 55.8, ROUGE-L 43.2, and factuality 88.6%, slightly below CodeT5 but statistically insignificant, demonstrating balance between technical correctness and humor engagement.
Differences in automatic metrics (p = 0.087) were statistically insignificant, confirming humor integration did not compromise accuracy while enhancing engagement and learner satisfaction.
83% of participants reported humor made explanations easier to remember, validating the system’s effectiveness in improving retention and long-term understanding of C++ concepts.
79% said humor reduced perceived difficulty of topics, demonstrating that playful explanations make advanced programming concepts less intimidating and increase learner confidence.
95% found humor appropriate and non-distracting, showing balance between playful tone and factual accuracy was successfully maintained in explanations.
11.4% of samples contained small factual errors, typically related to variable descriptions or outputs, requiring careful review for high-stakes educational applications.
8.7% of explanations were overly casual, which may affect professional contexts but generally enhances engagement for beginner learners.
6.2% of cases failed to account for uncommon syntax or scenarios, indicating the need for expanded dataset coverage for robust model performance.
3.1% of humor references were culturally specific, highlighting the importance of regionally adaptive humor to maintain relevance and learner engagement.
2.4% of explanations contained minor grammar errors, which generally do not impede comprehension but should be corrected for formal educational deployment.
Accuracy dropped to 76% for advanced template metaprogramming, suggesting future dataset expansion and fine-tuning are needed for comprehensive coverage of complex C++ constructs.
Limited examples of C++20/23 syntax reduce performance for new language features, requiring continuous dataset updates to maintain relevance and accuracy.
Embedded systems and OS-level C++ code show weaker performance, emphasizing the importance of domain-specific data for specialized learning or professional applications.
GitHub Copilot Chat achieved accuracy 4.1, engagement 3.2, response time 1.8s, demonstrating strong technical explanations but lower engagement and slower interactive performance.
Amazon CodeWhisperer Explain achieved accuracy 4.3, engagement 2.9, response time 2.1s, showing precise explanations but lower learner engagement and slower speed.
Tabnine Explain achieved accuracy 3.8, engagement 3.0, response time 1.5s, providing fast explanations with moderate accuracy and engagement.
Our system achieved accuracy 4.0, engagement 3.9, response time 0.25s, providing humor-aware explanations faster and more engaging than competitors while maintaining high accuracy.
Professional mode disables humor for academic use, ensuring contextually appropriate and culturally sensitive explanations without sacrificing factual correctness.
Automatic filters screen outputs to prevent hallucinations or inappropriate jokes, maintaining reliability and safety in educational applications.
Dataset is clean, non-proprietary, and fully annotated, supporting research, reproducibility, and ethical use in teaching programming.
Code-aware tokenization splits identifiers, preserves mappings, and ensures consistent subword references, enhancing model comprehension of code structure and variable relationships.
Normalization standardizes whitespace and indentation, removes accidental syntax errors, and prepares consistent, clean input for effective model training and evaluation.
Dataset split into 80% training, 10% validation, 10% testing with stratification by topic and difficulty, ensuring balanced coverage for robust performance evaluation.
CodeT5 transformer-based encoder-decoder architecture supports identifier-aware understanding, enabling accurate context-sensitive explanation generation for complex C++ code.
Stage 1 fine-tunes model on canonical comments with AdamW optimizer, learning rate 5×10⁻⁵, 10 epochs, and cross-entropy loss to maximize factual correctness.
Stage 2 fine-tunes model on humorous comments with learning rate 1×10⁻⁵, auxiliary factuality penalty, and nucleus sampling to maintain accuracy while enhancing engagement.
Beam search (beam=5) used for evaluation ensures high-probability explanations, while nucleus sampling (p=0.9) enables diverse and engaging interactive outputs.
Batch size 32, dropout 0.1, max sequence length 512, AdamW optimizer, and 5 runs with different random seeds averaged ensure stable, reproducible performance.
44% of dataset consists of repository-based educational examples, providing realistic, production-level C++ code for accurate model training.
26% of dataset sourced from textbooks and tutorials, covering structured pedagogy and ensuring foundational topic representation in the training data.
16% consists of instructor-authored examples, including error cases and clarifications, improving model robustness and coverage of learning challenges.
14% consists of humor-annotated examples, enabling model to generate playful, context-aware explanations without compromising factual correctness or technical clarity.

Gatik Alagh, Rhythm Chauhan, Jashanpreet Singh from Chandigarh University led the project under supervision of Mrs. Amandeep Kaur, combining technical and pedagogical expertise to develop the AI-powered C++ explainer.

All experiments conducted at Chandigarh University using Python, PyTorch, and Hugging Face Transformers, leveraging NVIDIA GPUs to fine-tune the CodeT5 model efficiently for humor-aware code explanations.

CodeT5 transformer-based encoder-decoder model selected for identifier-awareness, enabling context-sensitive understanding and generation of C++ explanations with high technical fidelity and adaptable style.

PyTorch with Hugging Face Transformers framework provided robust training utilities, tokenizers, and model interfaces to streamline fine-tuning, evaluation, and deployment of the AI-powered code explainer.

Code-aware tokenizer splits identifiers into readable subwords while preserving mappings, ensuring consistent interpretation of variable names, functions, and code structures during training and generation.

AdamW optimizer with mixed-precision training used to stabilize convergence, reduce memory consumption, and enhance performance across multiple epochs for both technical and humor-aware fine-tuning stages.

Automatic metrics (BLEU, ROUGE, CodeBLEU, factuality) and human studies were used to assess linguistic accuracy, technical correctness, engagement, and overall learning effectiveness of the AI explanations.
NVIDIA GPUs with CUDA acceleration enabled fast and efficient fine-tuning, allowing large-scale training on 5,000+ code-comment pairs while maintaining high reproducibility and performance.
Python, Pandas, and a custom annotator dashboard facilitated data collection, cleaning, annotation review, and integration of humor-labeled comments into the structured training dataset.
Gradio-based web app provided real-time code explanation testing, allowing users to input C++ code and receive immediate, humor-infused explanations to enhance learning engagement.

System transforms AI’s role in learning, providing empathetic tutors capable of accurate, engaging, and humorous explanations, improving retention, comprehension, and learner motivation in coding education.
Can be integrated into Codeforces, LeetCode, and other coding platforms as an interactive assistant to provide real-time, humor-aware code explanations during practice and competitions.

System can enhance learning management systems by embedding interactive, engaging explanations in course materials, quizzes, and assignments, supporting active learning and improved knowledge retention.

Smart classroom assistants can leverage the AI explainer to provide contextual, engaging explanations during lectures or programming labs, supporting instructor-led teaching with adaptive student feedback.
Interactive textbooks and mobile coding apps can include humor-aware explanations, bridging traditional learning and modern AI tutoring to make complex topics more approachable and enjoyable.
Plans include expanding the dataset to 50,000+ examples, covering C, Java, and Python, enabling cross-language learning and broader applicability of humor-aware code explanations.

Future models may incorporate memory of prior code snippets and explanations, allowing explanations to reference earlier context, improving coherence and learner understanding over multi-step exercises.

Adding text-to-speech functionality allows accessibility improvements, enabling learners to listen to humor-aware explanations and support auditory learners, visually impaired users, or multi-modal learning environments.
Humor can be dynamically adapted to learner age, region, and experience level, ensuring cultural sensitivity and improving engagement across diverse audiences.
RLHF can be used to fine-tune humor relevance dynamically, reinforcing explanations that maximize engagement, comprehension, and learner satisfaction without sacrificing accuracy.

AI-powered C++ explainer bridges technical correctness and learner engagement, producing human-like explanations with 35% higher engagement, 15% faster comprehension, and near-equal factual accuracy to technical baselines.
System demonstrates that AI can be both intelligent and entertaining, transforming programming education by combining humor, empathy, style, and precision in code explanation delivery.
Merging CodeT5 with humor-labeled comments creates a novel educational assistant capable of accurate, engaging, and fast explanations, inspiring future AI models to understand both code and learners.

Project led by Gatik Alagh, Rhythm Chauhan, Jashanpreet Singh, under supervision of Mrs. Amandeep Kaur, combining technical expertise, pedagogical insight, and model fine-tuning strategies for optimal educational performance.

Two-stage fine-tuning: first on canonical comments for accuracy, second on humor-annotated comments with factuality penalty, ensuring balance between technical correctness and engagement in generated explanations.

Gradio interface allowed real-time evaluation, providing learners with instant, humor-aware explanations, and enabling collection of user engagement, comprehension, and helpfulness feedback for model refinement.

Automatic metrics (BLEU, ROUGE, CodeBLEU, factuality) combined with human studies (engagement, comprehension time, helpfulness, anxiety reduction, task completion) provide comprehensive assessment of explanation quality.
Metrics quantify linguistic similarity, syntax accuracy, and factual correctness of generated explanations, ensuring high-quality outputs while measuring alignment with human-annotated references.

Human metrics assess engagement, comprehension speed, helpfulness, and anxiety, providing insight into practical learning impact beyond raw accuracy, validating effectiveness of humor-aware explanations.

Humor-aware explanations slightly below CodeT5 in BLEU, CodeBLEU, and ROUGE-L but statistically insignificant, showing engagement can improve without compromising technical accuracy or factual correctness.
Engagement increased 39% compared to baseline, demonstrating humor’s significant role in maintaining attention and motivating learners in challenging programming topics.
Average comprehension time reduced by 15.5%, confirming humor and clarity in explanations accelerate understanding and practical application of code concepts.
Helpfulness rating improved by 28%, showing learners find humor-aware explanations more usable and applicable than purely technical outputs.
Anxiety reduction improved 31%, demonstrating that playful, accurate explanations make advanced programming topics less intimidating, increasing learner confidence.
Task completion rates increased by 11.5 points, indicating improved learner persistence and problem-solving ability with engaging, humor-aware explanations.
Response time of 0.25 seconds allows interactive, IDE-ready explanations, providing near-instant feedback for learners and outperforming commercial code explanation tools by an order of magnitude.
System represents a breakthrough in educational AI, combining humor, engagement, and technical accuracy, creating tools that understand both code and learners effectively.
Model can support instructors in classrooms, coding labs, or online courses, providing engaging explanations that complement lectures and improve learner outcomes.
With expanded dataset and multi-language support, system can scale to large educational platforms, adapting explanations dynamically to learner proficiency, language, and cultural context.
Exploration of RLHF, cross-language datasets, adaptive humor, contextual memory, and voice-based explanations provides pathways for continuous improvement and broader impact in programming education.

System demonstrates the value of combining AI understanding of code with educational psychology insights, improving retention, comprehension, and learner motivation through humor-infused explanations.
Fine-tuning CodeT5 on humor-annotated data validates a methodology for integrating technical accuracy and stylistic engagement, providing a blueprint for similar AI educational tools.
Structured code-comment pairs with canonical and humor annotations offer a reusable, high-quality dataset for training future AI models in code explanation and educational contexts.
System fosters accessible, engaging, and effective coding education, promoting inclusion, reducing learner anxiety, and inspiring future AI-driven educational innovations globally.
BLEU measures n-gram overlap between generated explanations and reference text, indicating syntactic similarity, precision, and quality of generated code summaries in a quantifiable manner.
CodeBLEU extends BLEU by incorporating identifier and syntax structure evaluation, ensuring code-specific correctness in generated explanations beyond general text similarity.
ROUGE-L measures the longest common subsequence between reference and generated explanations, assessing recall and content overlap to evaluate completeness and accuracy.
Factuality Rate quantifies how accurately generated explanations reference variables, functions, and outputs, ensuring explanations maintain technical correctness even when humor is added.
Engagement is rated 1–5, capturing user attention and interest, showing how humor and interactive explanations increase learner involvement by 39.3% compared to baseline models.
Average comprehension time is measured in minutes; humor-aware outputs reduced understanding time from 8.4 to 7.1 minutes, indicating a 15.5% improvement in learning efficiency.
Helpfulness quantifies how well explanations aid learner understanding; ratings increased from 3.2 to 4.1, showing enhanced usability and relatability of humor-aware AI-generated explanations.
Measured on a scale, anxiety reduction shows learners feel less stressed; humor decreased anxiety ratings from 2.9 to 3.8, representing a 31% reduction in perceived difficulty.
Task completion percentage increased from 73.2% to 84.7% with humor-enhanced explanations, showing learners successfully solved more coding problems and persisted longer during exercises.
Cohen's d > 0.8 across engagement, comprehension, and anxiety metrics indicates statistically and practically significant improvements, confirming the real impact of humor integration.
DeepCom achieved BLEU 22.1, CodeBLEU 28.4, ROUGE-L 31.2, factuality 78.2%, providing a baseline reference for accuracy compared to modern transformer-based models.
CodeBERT achieved BLEU 35.7, CodeBLEU 52.3, ROUGE-L 41.8, factuality 89.4%, demonstrating improved syntactic and semantic understanding over earlier Seq2Seq systems.
CodeT5 achieved BLEU 41.2, CodeBLEU 58.9, ROUGE-L 45.3, factuality 91.7%, establishing a strong technical baseline before humor-aware fine-tuning.
The humor-aware system achieved BLEU 39.4, CodeBLEU 55.8, ROUGE-L 43.2, factuality 88.6%, maintaining accuracy while significantly improving engagement and user experience.
11.4% of outputs contained small factual errors, mostly missing minor details, but these did not affect overall understanding or correctness in a practical learning context.
8.7% of explanations had slightly informal tone; humor maintained engagement without disrupting technical clarity or factual accuracy.
6.2% of code samples missed rare or boundary conditions, highlighting areas for dataset expansion to cover uncommon but important constructs.
3.1% of humor references were culturally specific, suggesting adaptive humor mechanisms are required for global audiences to maintain engagement and relevance.
2.4% of outputs had minor grammar problems due to humor integration; readability remained high and did not compromise learning effectiveness.
Accuracy dropped to 76% for advanced template metaprogramming, showing challenges in explaining complex abstractions and the need for targeted training examples.
Limited exposure to C++20/23 features reduced accuracy, highlighting necessity for continuous dataset updates to reflect evolving language standards.
Performance decreased for embedded and OS-specific code; future training requires specialized examples to maintain factual correctness in niche domains.
Copilot Chat scored 4.1 accuracy, 3.2 engagement, 1.8s response; baseline for evaluating humor-enhanced AI system performance and speed advantages.
Amazon CodeWhisperer achieved 4.3 accuracy, 2.9 engagement, 2.1s response time; slightly higher technical correctness but lower engagement than proposed model.
Tabnine Explain reached 3.8 accuracy, 3.0 engagement, 1.5s response; demonstrates faster but less engaging explanations than humor-aware system.
0.25 seconds per explanation, making the system highly interactive and 10× faster than commercial alternatives without compromising factual correctness.
Engagement improved 39.3%, confirming humor substantially increases learner attention and motivation during code comprehension tasks.
Average comprehension time decreased by 15.5%, from 8.4 to 7.1 minutes, showing that humor-aware explanations accelerate understanding of complex C++ code.
Ratings rose from 3.2 to 4.1, indicating that learners find humor-aware explanations more practical, relatable, and easier to apply than baseline outputs.
Humor decreased learner anxiety by 31%, making advanced C++ topics less intimidating and fostering more confidence in problem-solving.
Completion rate increased 11.5 points from 73.2% to 84.7%, showing humor improves persistence and practical learning outcomes.
83% of participants reported that humor made explanations easier to remember, enhancing long-term retention of code concepts.
79% stated humor reduced perceived difficulty, making complex topics approachable and fostering willingness to attempt challenging exercises.
95% agreed humor was suitable and not distracting, confirming balance between engagement and factual accuracy.

Gatik Alagh, Rhythm Chauhan, Jashanpreet Singh, and Mrs. Amandeep Kaur designed, trained, and evaluated the model, ensuring technical and educational efficacy.
Stage 1 fine-tuning uses canonical_comment pairs with AdamW optimizer, 5×10⁻⁵ learning rate, 10 epochs, and cross-entropy loss to maximize factual correctness of explanations.
Stage 2 fine-tuning uses humorous_comment pairs with lower learning rate 1×10⁻⁵, auxiliary factuality penalty, and nucleus sampling (p=0.9) to generate accurate yet engaging explanations.
Beam search with beam=5 is applied during evaluation to select the most probable and coherent explanations among multiple candidate sequences.
Nucleus sampling (p=0.9) introduces controlled randomness in interactive generation, producing diverse humor-infused explanations while retaining technical correctness.
Batch size is set to 32 to balance GPU memory usage and training stability for transformer-based model training.
Maximum input and output token sequence length is 512, ensuring complete code snippets and explanations are captured without truncation.
Dropout rate 0.1 is used to reduce overfitting by randomly deactivating neurons during training, improving generalization to unseen code snippets.
Five random seeds are used for training runs, with results averaged to ensure statistical reliability and reduce variance in performance metrics.
Identifiers in camelCase and snake_case are split into subwords for improved context understanding while maintaining mapping for consistent variable references.
Whitespace and indentation are standardized, accidental syntax errors removed unless intentional, ensuring clean inputs for model training.
Dataset is split 80% training, 10% validation, 10% testing with stratification based on topic and difficulty to balance coverage and performance evaluation.
Formal and accurate explanation of code snippet used to train the model for factual correctness during technical fine-tuning.
Accurate yet playful explanation used during humor-aware fine-tuning to increase engagement without reducing technical correctness.
Dataset includes difficulty, topic, number of lines, and key code features to inform model training and allow stratified evaluation.
5,000+ code-comment pairs, including repository examples, textbooks, instructor-authored, and humor-annotated examples for comprehensive training coverage.
2,200 examples (44%) sourced from repositories provide realistic, production-level code for accurate model understanding.
1,300 examples (26%) provide pedagogical clarity and ensure coverage of standard C++ topics for beginner-friendly explanations.
800 examples (16%) include error cases, clarifications, and advanced patterns, supporting nuanced explanation generation.
700 examples (14%) provide curated humorous explanations, enabling the model to learn playful yet factual commentary.
Multiple annotators verified each code-comment pair, resolving disagreements by majority vote to maintain high-quality training data.
BLEU, CodeBLEU, ROUGE-L, and factuality are used to quantify linguistic quality, code-specific correctness, and explanation accuracy.
132 participants across three universities evaluated engagement, comprehension, helpfulness, anxiety, follow-up questions, and task completion rates.
66 participants received CodeT5-only outputs to provide a comparison point for humor-aware model performance.
66 participants received humor-enhanced explanations to measure improvements in engagement, comprehension speed, and learning effectiveness.
Engagement percentage increase = ((Proposed rating - Baseline rating) / Baseline rating) × 100; achieved +39.3%.
Comprehension reduction percentage = ((Baseline time - Proposed time) / Baseline time) × 100; achieved 15.5% faster understanding.
Helpfulness increase = Proposed rating - Baseline rating; showed +0.9 points, indicating more practical explanations.
Anxiety reduction percentage = ((Proposed - Baseline) / Baseline) × 100; achieved 31% reduction in perceived stress.
Task completion difference = Proposed % - Baseline %; achieved +11.5 points, showing better persistence and problem-solving.
Cohen's d > 0.8 for all metrics indicates large effect sizes, confirming improvements are both statistically and practically meaningful.
