A for loop iterates a fixed number of times using syntax: for(initialization; condition; increment){ /* code */ }.
While loop executes as long as the condition is true: while(condition){ /* code */ } useful for unknown iteration counts.
Do-while executes the block at least once and checks condition after: do{ /* code */ } while(condition); ensuring one-time execution.
Conditional execution: if(condition){ /* code */ } else { /* code */ } allows branching based on boolean evaluation.
An if statement inside another allows multiple-level conditional checks: if(condition1){ if(condition2){ /* code */ } }.
Switch executes a code block matching a case value: switch(variable){ case value: /* code */ break; default: /* code */ }.
Break immediately exits the nearest enclosing loop or switch statement to stop further iteration.
Continue skips the remaining code in current iteration and moves to next iteration in loops.
A function is a reusable block: return_type functionName(parameters){ /* code */ } to perform tasks modularly.
Declaration specifies signature: return_type functionName(parameters); Definition provides full code body: return_type functionName(parameters){ /* code */ }.
Multiple functions with same name but different parameters; compiler resolves correct version based on argument types or count.
Function calling itself to solve subproblems; ensure base case to terminate recursion and prevent stack overflow.
Function receives a copy of variable; modifications inside function do not affect original variable outside.
Function receives reference to variable; modifications inside function affect the original variable.
Compiler replaces inline function call with code body to reduce call overhead for small functions: inline return_type func(){ /* code */ }.
Function can have default arguments: void func(int a=5){ /* code */ } allowing omission of arguments when calling.
Using const prevents function from modifying parameter value: void func(const int a){ /* code */ }.
Static variable retains value across function calls, initialized only once: static int counter = 0;.
Global accessible throughout program; local accessible only in block/function scope; naming conflicts can occur if not careful.
Reference is an alias for existing variable: int &ref = var; changes affect original variable directly.
Pointer stores memory address: int* ptr = &var; allows dynamic memory access and indirect manipulation of variables.
Adding/subtracting integers to pointers moves across memory blocks based on data type size.
Access or modify value at pointer address: *ptr = 10; retrieves or changes value pointed to by ptr.
Pointer with value NULL or nullptr points to nothing; safe checks prevent runtime errors.
Allocate memory at runtime using new: int* arr = new int[10]; remember to free with delete[].
Frees dynamically allocated memory: delete ptr; or delete[] arr; prevents memory leaks.
Pointer itself constant: int* const ptr; or pointer to constant value: const int* ptr; controlling mutability.
Array stores fixed-size sequence of elements: int arr[5]; access via index arr[0] to arr[4].
Arrays of arrays: int arr[3][4]; accessed using row-column indexing arr[i][j].
C++ strings store text: std::string str = "hello"; supports concatenation, length, and indexing operations.
C-string is char array terminated by '\0'; std::string is safer, dynamic, and provides methods for manipulation.
Struct groups multiple variables: struct Point{ int x; int y; }; allows custom data types.
Class defines blueprint: class Car{ /* attributes and methods */ }; object is instance: Car myCar;.
Class data protected using private/public access; ensures controlled access to internal state via methods.
Special function called automatically on object creation to initialize attributes: ClassName(){ /* code */ }.
Special function called when object is destroyed: ~ClassName(){ /* cleanup */ } frees resources.
Control visibility: public (accessible), private (restricted), protected (derived classes) for data/methods.
Derive class from base: class Child: public Parent{ }; reuses and extends functionality.
Ability to take multiple forms; compile-time via function overloading, runtime via virtual functions and overriding.
Enables dynamic binding for derived class overrides: virtual void func(){ /* code */ } ensures correct method called at runtime.
Abstract method: virtual void func() = 0; forces derived classes to implement, creating interface-like behavior.
Define custom behavior for operators in classes: ClassName operator+(const ClassName &obj){ /* code */ }.
Friend function can access private/protected members of a class: friend void func(ClassName &obj); used for flexibility.
Templates create generic functions or classes: template<typename T> T add(T a, T b){ return a+b; } for type-independent code.
Catch runtime errors using try-catch: try{ /* code */ } catch(exception &e){ /* handle */ } prevents crashes.
Use throw keyword to signal error: throw std::runtime_error("Error message"); handled by catch blocks.
Vector is dynamic array: std::vector<int> v; supports push_back, size, indexing, and iteration.
Map stores key-value pairs: std::map<int, string> m; provides fast lookup, insertion, and ordered keys.
Set stores unique elements in sorted order: std::set<int> s; supports insertion, deletion, and searching.
Iterator traverses STL containers: for(auto it = v.begin(); it != v.end(); ++it){ /* code */ }.
Anonymous function: auto f = [](int a,int b){ return a+b; }; useful for short inline functionality.
Manage memory automatically: std::unique_ptr, std::shared_ptr; prevent leaks by automatic destruction.
Compile-time constant evaluation: constexpr int square(int x){ return x*x; }; improves performance.
List is a doubly-linked list: std::list<int> l; supports insertion, deletion, and traversal efficiently at any position.
Deque is double-ended queue: std::deque<int> d; supports insertion and deletion from both ends with random access.
Stack is LIFO container: std::stack<int> s; push(), pop(), top() manage last-in-first-out behavior.
Queue is FIFO container: std::queue<int> q; push(), pop(), front() manage first-in-first-out behavior.
Priority queue stores elements in sorted order: std::priority_queue<int> pq; top() gives highest priority element.
Unordered_map stores key-value pairs with hash table: std::unordered_map<int,string> um; provides O(1) average lookup.
Unordered_set stores unique elements with hash table: std::unordered_set<int> us; allows fast insertion and search.
Simplified loop for container traversal: for(auto &x: container){ /* code */ } automatically iterates all elements.
Auto lets compiler deduce type automatically: auto x = 10; simplifies declarations and improves readability.
Convert between types: static_cast<int>(x), dynamic_cast<Class*>(ptr), const_cast<Type>(expr), reinterpret_cast<Type>(ptr) for specific conversions.
Enum defines set of named constants: enum Color{RED, GREEN, BLUE}; improves code readability and type safety.
Scoped enum prevents global pollution: enum class Color{RED, GREEN, BLUE}; accessed as Color::RED for clarity.
Operators like &, |, ^, ~, <<, >> allow manipulation of individual bits for optimization or algorithm purposes.
Compile-time conditional: if constexpr(condition){ /* code */ } evaluates condition at compile time to optimize code paths.
Efficiently transfer resources: T obj2 = std::move(obj1); avoids unnecessary copying, especially for large objects.
Rvalue reference binds to temporary object: T&& ref = T(); enables move semantics for performance.
Capture variables by value in lambda: [x](){ /* code */ } creates local copy inside lambda scope.
Capture variables by reference: [&x](){ /* code */ } allows modifying external variable inside lambda.
Allows modifying captured-by-value variables inside lambda: [x]() mutable { x++; }.
C++17 feature to apply operator over parameter pack: (args + ...); simplifies template code for variadic arguments.
C++17 feature: auto [x,y] = pair; extracts multiple values at once from tuple, pair, or struct.
C++17 std::optional<T> stores value or nothing: optional<int> opt; use opt.has_value() and opt.value() safely.
C++17 std::variant<Ts...> stores one of multiple types safely: std::variant<int,string> v; access using std::get.
C++17 std::any stores any type dynamically: std::any a = 10; type-safe retrieval using std::any_cast.
C++11 std::thread allows multi-threading: std::thread t(func,args); t.join() waits for thread completion.
std::mutex protects shared resources in multi-threading: std::mutex m; m.lock()/m.unlock() or std::lock_guard for safety.
std::condition_variable allows threads to wait for specific conditions safely in concurrent programming.
std::promise sets a value from one thread; std::future retrieves it in another thread; used for async communication.
std::atomic<T> provides lock-free thread-safe operations for shared variables in multi-threaded programs.
Multiple threads can share variables safely with mutexes, atomics, or std::shared_ptr for proper memory management.
std::unique_ptr owns resource exclusively; std::shared_ptr allows multiple owners with reference counting.
std::weak_ptr references shared_ptr without increasing reference count; prevents circular references and memory leaks.
Use lambda for compact operations: std::for_each(v.begin(),v.end(), [](int x){ /* code */ }); simplifies code readability.
std::sort(v.begin(),v.end(), [](int a,int b){ return a>b; }); sorts container using custom comparison logic.
std::accumulate(begin,end,init) computes sum (or other binary op) over container elements efficiently.
std::find(begin,end,value) returns iterator to element if found or end if not found in container.
std::count(begin,end,value) returns number of occurrences of value in container.
std::transform(begin,end,output,func) applies function to each element producing transformed container.
std::for_each(begin,end,func) applies function to every element of container, useful for printing or modifications.
std::lower_bound finds first element >= value; std::upper_bound finds first element > value in sorted container.
std::binary_search(begin,end,value) returns true if value exists in sorted container; efficient O(log n) lookup.
std::reverse(begin,end) reverses elements in container in-place efficiently.
std::rotate(begin, middle, end) shifts elements so middle becomes new first element, preserving order.
std::remove or std::remove_if shifts elements to erase unwanted values; erase() is needed to actually remove them from container.
std::next_permutation(begin,end) rearranges elements to next lexicographical permutation; useful for combinatorial algorithms.
std::prev_permutation(begin,end) rearranges elements to previous lexicographical permutation for combinatorial tasks.
std::min(a,b) returns smaller; std::max(a,b) returns larger; overloadable for custom types with comparison operators.
std::clamp(val,min,max) restricts value to specified range, ensuring it stays between min and max inclusive.
std::gcd(a,b) computes greatest common divisor; std::lcm(a,b) computes least common multiple; used in numeric computations.
Use % operator for remainder; essential for cyclic operations, hashing, and mathematical algorithms.
std::pow(base,exp) computes base raised to exponent; works for integers and floating-point numbers.
Use + operator or append(): std::string s = "Hello" + std::string(" World"); combines two strings into one.
s.find(sub) returns index of first occurrence of substring sub or std::string::npos if not found.
s.substr(pos,len) returns substring starting at pos of length len; useful for extracting parts of a string.
s.replace(pos,len,new_str) replaces len characters at pos with new_str; modifies original string.
s.insert(pos,str) inserts str at position pos in original string; shifts existing characters.
s.erase(pos,len) removes len characters starting from pos; reduces string size.
s.empty() returns true if string has zero length; useful for validation.
s.length() or s.size() returns number of characters in string; same functionality.
s1.compare(s2) returns 0 if equal, <0 if s1<s2, >0 if s1>s2; useful for lexicographical comparison.
std::stoi(s) converts numeric string to int; std::stol, std::stoll for larger integers.
std::to_string(n) converts integer n to string representation; works for float, double, etc.
Use isalpha(c), isdigit(c), isspace(c) to verify character type; cctype library provides these.
toupper(c) converts character to uppercase; tolower(c) converts to lowercase; useful for normalization.
std::stringstream ss; ss << "123"; ss >> n; converts string to number or formats text efficiently.
v.push_back(x) appends element x at end of vector; dynamically increases size.
v.pop_back() removes last element; reduces vector size; no return value.
v.size() returns current number of elements; v.capacity() shows allocated memory size.
v.clear() removes all elements but does not change capacity; resets vector.
v[i] or v.at(i) accesses i-th element; at() provides bounds checking and throws exception if out of range.
v.insert(pos, x) inserts element x at iterator position pos; shifts elements to the right.
v.erase(pos) removes element at iterator pos; use range erase(begin,end) for multiple elements.
v.resize(n) adjusts vector size to n; adds default elements if expanding, truncates if reducing.
v.empty() returns true if vector has zero elements; useful before access or deletion.
for(auto &x:v){ /* code */ } iterates over each element; avoids index-based access.
std::set<int> s stores unique sorted elements; insert, erase, find provide efficient operations.
std::multiset<int> ms allows duplicates; elements remain sorted; find returns iterator to first occurrence.
std::map<int,string> m stores key-value pairs sorted by key; m[key]=value inserts or updates.
std::multimap<int,string> mm allows multiple identical keys; stores values in order of insertion for same key.
std::pair<int,string> p = {1,"A"}; p.first and p.second access elements; often used in map iteration.
std::tuple<int,string,double> t(1,"A",3.14); access with std::get<0>(t), std::get<1>(t), etc.
auto p = std::make_pair(1,"A"); int x; string y; std::tie(x,y) = p; unpacks pair efficiently.
std::stack<int> st; st.push(10); st.pop(); top() returns current top element without removal.
std::queue<int> q; q.push(5); q.pop(); front() returns first element; back() returns last.
std::priority_queue<int> pq by default stores max element at top; push() and pop() maintain heap property.
std::priority_queue<int,std::vector<int>,std::greater<int>> pq; smallest element at top; useful in algorithms.
std::unordered_set<int> us stores unique elements using hash table; average O(1) for insert, find, erase.
std::unordered_map<int,string> um stores key-value pairs using hash table; average O(1) operations.
std::reverse(v.begin(),v.end()) reverses all elements in vector or container; in-place operation.
std::sort(v.begin(),v.end()) sorts container in ascending order; use custom comparator for different criteria.
std::lower_bound(v.begin(),v.end(),x) returns iterator to first element >= x; requires sorted container.
std::upper_bound(v.begin(),v.end(),x) returns iterator to first element > x; used in range queries.
std::binary_search(v.begin(),v.end(),x) checks existence of x in sorted container; returns bool efficiently.
std::accumulate(v.begin(),v.end(),0) sums elements in container; third argument is initial value.
std::count(v.begin(),v.end(),x) returns number of occurrences of x in container; simple frequency check.
std::find(v.begin(),v.end(),x) returns iterator to first occurrence or end() if not found.
std::transform(v.begin(),v.end(),out.begin(),func) applies func to each element producing output container.
std::for_each(v.begin(),v.end(),[](int x){ /* code */ }); applies lambda to all elements; concise iteration.
std::next_permutation(v.begin(),v.end()) generates next lexicographical permutation of container elements.
std::prev_permutation(v.begin(),v.end()) generates previous lexicographical permutation of container elements.
for(int i=0;i<n;i++){ /* code */ } executes code block n times; i is loop counter.
while(condition){ /* code */ } repeats until condition becomes false; check before execution.
do{ /* code */ }while(condition); executes code at least once; checks condition after execution.
break exits the innermost loop immediately; useful to stop on condition.
continue skips current iteration and moves to next loop iteration; used to avoid nested ifs.
ReturnType funcName(parameters) { /* code */ } defines reusable code block; parameters passed by value or reference.
Multiple functions with same name but different parameters; compiler selects based on argument types.
void func(int x=5){ /* code */ } allows calling func() without passing x; uses default value.
inline void func(){ /* code */ } hints compiler to expand function at call site; reduces overhead.
Function calls itself to solve smaller sub-problems; always include base case to avoid infinite recursion.
int factorial(int n){ return n<=1?1:n*factorial(n-1); } calculates n! using recursion.
int fib(int n){ return n<=1?n:fib(n-1)+fib(n-2); } generates n-th Fibonacci number recursively.
void func(int x){ /* code */ } original variable unchanged; copy passed to function.
void func(int &x){ /* code */ } allows function to modify original variable directly.
void func(const int &x){ /* code */ } prevents modification while avoiding copy overhead.
int *ptr = &var; stores memory address of var; *ptr dereferences value.
ptr+1 moves pointer to next element (based on type size); useful in arrays and buffer traversal.
int *arr = new int[n]; allocates memory at runtime; must delete[] arr to free.
delete ptr; delete[] arr; frees dynamically allocated memory to prevent leaks.
int arr[5]; stores fixed-size elements; access with index arr[i]; contiguous memory.
int arr[3][4]; stores rows and columns; access arr[i][j]; useful for matrices.
std::vector<int> v is dynamic; array fixed-size; vector has push_back, size(), capacity(), etc.
class MyClass{ public: int x; void func(){}; }; defines blueprint for objects with members and methods.
MyClass obj; creates instance obj of MyClass; access members with obj.x or obj.func().
MyClass(){ /* code */ } initializes object on creation; can be overloaded for multiple behaviors.
~MyClass(){ /* code */ } called automatically when object goes out of scope; cleans resources.
class MyClass{ private: int x; }; members not accessible outside class; encapsulation principle.
class MyClass{ public: int x; }; accessible anywhere; provides interface for object interaction.
int getX(){return x;} void setX(int val){x=val;} encapsulates access to private members.
class Derived: public Base{}; Derived inherits members and methods from Base; promotes code reuse.
Ability to use base class reference to access derived class methods; dynamic behavior via virtual functions.
virtual void func(){}; enables runtime polymorphism; overridden in derived classes.
virtual void func()=0; makes class abstract; must be implemented in derived class.
Class with at least one pure virtual function; cannot instantiate object directly; used as interface.
Overriding: derived redefines base function; overloading: same name, different parameters.
friend void func(MyClass &obj); can access private/protected members; breaks encapsulation carefully.
int getX() const { return x; } guarantees method does not modify object state.
static int x; shared across all instances; access with ClassName::x; persists for program lifetime.
Overload operators like +, -, <<, >> for custom behavior with user-defined types.
template<typename T> T add(T a,T b){ return a+b; } allows generic programming for multiple types.
template<typename T> void func(T x){ /* code */ } works for int, double, string, etc.
template<typename T> class MyClass{ T data; }; creates classes for any type without duplication.
try{ /* code */ } catch(exception &e){ /* handle */ } manages runtime errors gracefully.
throw runtime_error("Error"); raises exception; transfers control to catch block.
catch(int e){ } catch(string e){ } handles different exception types separately.
std::ifstream fin("file.txt"); fin >> data; reads file contents into variables.
std::ofstream fout("file.txt"); fout << data; writes data to file; creates file if not exist.
while(fin >> x){ /* code */ } reads until end; eof flag indicates file end.
Use #include <cmath>; functions like sqrt(), pow(), abs(), ceil(), floor(), sin(), cos(), tan() are available.
Use #include <cstdlib> rand()%100 gives number 0-99; srand(time(0)) seeds generator for variation.
